sect1.title: Welcome to &argo;
sect1.para: Welcome to &argo; from the &argo-project-link; team at &tigris-link;. &argo; is a powerful yet easy-to-use interactive, graphical software design environment that supports the design, development and documentation of object-oriented software applications. It leverages the Write Once, Run Anywhere promise of the Java2 platform to allow you to design great object-oriented software in your preferred Operating System environment.

If you are familiar with a family of software applications called Computer Aided Software Engineering (CASE) tools then you should find &argo; instantly familiar. It is an interactive, graphical modelling CASE tool that is easy to install, learn, use and customise for your own unique design environment. It is built on an extendible foundation of open standards (or industry standards) to ensure interoperability with the rest of the industry. You can share designs created with &argo; and collaborate with colleagues using other tools easily because of it's support for open standards.

The typical users of &argo; include software designers & architects, software developers, business analysts, systems analysts and other professionals involved in the analysis, design and development of software applications. It has a number of features (some unique) that enables it to better support these users in the design of software systems:
Uses the open standard Unified Modelling Language (UML) as the language for documenting and communicating object-oriented designs
Supports open standards including XML Metadata Interchange format (XMI), Scalable Vector Graphics format (SVG) and Portable Graphics Markup Language natively and as formats for the communicating design information with external systems
Is a 100% Java application to ensure that it is available for use on all the major OS platforms plus any other OS an implementation of the Java2 platform exists
Is an Open Source product that enables it's users to extend or customize it. Many users also eventually become contributors to the future development of &argo; itself. On particularly important group of users are researchers and research groups who often endow &argo; with state-of-the-art features ahead of other CASE tools
Incorporates a number of specific cognitive features to better support the design process:
reflection-in-action
opportunistic design
comprehension and problem solving
&argo; was originally a product of a research programme at UCL led by Jason E. Robbins.

caution.title: &argo; version 0.8.x or earlier
caution.para: This guide is designed for the 0.9.x versions of &argo;. Many of the comments may also be applicable to earlier versions of the software but that has not been tested.

sect1.title: About this guide...
sect1.para: This guide - the &document-title; - is provided to help you get up and running as quickly as possible with &argo;. It provides step-by-step instructions for obtaining and installing &argo;, performing common tasks, and outlines your options for contacting &argo-project-link; team should you need further support or to contribute to &argo;'s development.

sect2.title: In this guide, you will find...
sect2.para:
The remainder of this chapter includes information about documentation conventions and what you need to know to be able to use &argo; effectively. Here's what you can expect to find in the remaining chapters in this guide:
Download and Installation instructions
Basic tutorial/introduction to &argo; - step-by-step procedures on essentials
Support option - mailing list, resources, contributions, source code/CVS etc..

sect2.title: In this guide, you will not find...
sect2.para: This guide is not a complete user or reference manual for &argo;. The &argo-website; has information about the status of other &argo; documentation including a user manual.

This guide does not attempt to teach you about UML, XMI, SVG or any other such standards that &argo; implements or supports. Neither does it attempt to teach you about the Java platform or your Operating System platform.

sect2.title: What you should already know
sect2.para: This guide assumes that you know how to use your computer. It also assumes that you have some knowledge of object-oriented software design given your interest in &argo;. You should be familiar with the process of installing software applications on your computer although full installation instructions are given for &argo;.
Once &argo; is installed, it is assumed that you know how to point, click, and drag with a mouse or another pointing device and that you can use a keyboard.

sect2.title: Documentation conventions
sect2.para: Before reading this guide, please take a moment to ensure that you understand the conventions followed in the guide. This will help you to use the guide more effectively.

sect3.title: Conventions related to the use of the mouse

row.entry: Press the primary mouse button (usually the left mouse button).
Press the primary mouse button quickly twice.
Press the secondary mouse button (usually the right mouse button).
Click File on the top-level menu bar and, click the New option in the displayed 'File' menu.
Click Create on the top-level menu bar, click Diagrams in the 'Create' menu that appears, click the ClassDiagram option in the 'Diagrams' submenu that appears.
Click and drag to highlight text.

sect3.title: Conventions related to the use of the keyboard

row.entry: Press the Enter key on your keyboard.
Press the Control key and the Shift key at the same time.
Press the Control key and while keeping it pressed, press the C key at the same time.
